author: Jonathan Walker
title: New UKIP leader Diane James urged to make it 'the party for the North'
text:
New UKIP leader Diane James urged to make it 'the party for the North' 17:06, 16 Sep 2016 17:06, 16 Sep 2016 By Jonathan Walker North East MEP Diane James urged to target the region and unify the party after taking over from Nigel Farage Shares Get daily news by email Ben Birchall/PA Wire Diane James celebrates makes a speech after being named as the new leader of Ukip 
eThe new leader of UKIP , Diane James, has been told to turn it into a party for working class northerners. 
The advice came from its North East MEP, Jonathan Arnott, who also stressed the need to unite the party which has been riven by divisions in recent years. 
Mr Arnott had been a candidate in the contest to replace Nigel Farage, but pulled out after deciding he had little chance of winning. 
Speaking from the party conference in Bournemouth, he welcomed the election of Ms James, an MEP for the South East region. 
She is the party’s deputy chairman and secured nearly half the votes after going up against four other hopefuls. Ian Forsyth/Getty Images Jonathan Arnott, the EU Budget spokesman for the UK Independence Party 
Mr Arnott said: “We have had the leadership contest and the first duty of those in the party is to unite behind the new leader and give them a chance to show what they are about. 
“Diane has a lot of positives, in particular her ability to portray policies in a positive way which will appeal beyond UKIP’s core demographic. 
“There is a huge opportunity for the party, but it also requites the party to unite.” 
He added: “UKIP has a massive role to play in terms of ensuring Brexit means what it is supposed to mean. 
“And in the North we have a massive role in terms of appealing to the working class voters that Labour has abandoned.” 
Other candidates included former Stockton councillor and Eaglescliffe Tesco worker Phillip Broughton, a former professional wrestler who ran his own wrestling business. He came fourth. Ben Birchall/PA Wire Diane James celebrates with Nigel Farage after being named as the new leader of Ukip 
Speaking after the result was announced, Ms James insisted that Brexit must mean “100% EU exit ”, and said UKIP’s “people’s army” must keep up the pressure on Theresa May’s Government. 
She said: “And Mrs May - from one grammar school girl to another, stop the faff, stop the fudge and the farce, get on with it. 
“Evoke Article 50 and give UKIP the best Christmas present we could ever have.” 
As she took to the stage to take over from Mr Farage as the party’s new leader, Ms James paid tribute to the work of her predecessor. 
But she stressed that she must be allowed to lead the party in her own way, saying she would not be a “Nigel-like, not even Nigel-lite”. 
Earlier, Mr Farage was given a hero’s welcome as he spoke to party activists. Dan Kitwood/Getty Images Nigel Farage 
He said he has given UKIP “absolutely all of me” as he revealed plans to tour Europe to foster Brexit-style “independence movements” now that he has stepped down as party leader. 
Mr Farage said: “Today closes the chapter of what has been a very extraordinary few years. I honestly, looking back, could never really have dreamt that we would have achieved what we have. 
“I have put absolutely all of me into this. I literally couldn’t have worked any harder or couldn’t have been more determined. In a sense, I guess it has been my life’s work to try to help get this party to this point. 
“I frankly don’t think I could do any more. I think, folks, I’ve done my bit.” 
As the crowd whooped and cheered, he said he will remain in politics touring Europe encouraging others to follow Britain out of the European Union. 
Mr Farage received a standing ovation from the crowd, many of whom waved Union Flags and placards emblazoned with pictures of his face, as he left the stage played out to David Bowie’s Heroes. 
But in a sign of the divisions within UKIP, outgoing deputy leader Paul Nuttall said he fears “for the very future of our party” unless the in-fighting that has racked the organisation is resolved. 
Speaking in front of delegates in the conference hall, he said: “I will be frank at this point, because I can be now. UKIP has not been a happy camp for over a year, and the animosity has spilt over into the media. 
“No one, no one has emerged from this with their head held high.”
